Dylan Hughes
16 Wins A Ring
Jan 20

How Good Can Aaron Gordon Be?

Orlando’s athletic forward is coming along nicely, and may have a comparable ceiling as a fellow 2014 draftee

Despite arguably being the team’s best future talent, the Orlando Magic have taken two separate paths to alter the development of Aaron Gordon. Still, Gordon is starting to figure things out and has the potential to grow into a very good player, so long as the Magic get out of his way.

With Channing Frye, Kyle O’Quinn and Tobias Harris splitting the minutes at power forward, Gordon didn’t get much opportunity in his 2014–15 rookie season. Orlando’s developmental focus was on Victor Oladipo and Gordon’s fellow rookie Elfrid Payton, with the presumed plan to be getting Gordon real minutes the next season.

Gordon only appeared in 47 games his rookie season, averaging 17 minutes per game.

In 2015–16 — Gordon’s sophomore year — Orlando’s power forward position was still rather clogged with Harris and Frye still on board, along with Andrew Nicholson getting more minutes than the year prior.

However, after Orlando shed themselves of Harris and Frye in two separate trades just prior to the trade deadline, Gordon’s big opportunity had finally come.

Gordon showed flashes but certainly hadn’t “arrived.” With a full season as the starting power forward to look forward to, Gordon was set to have by far his best season yet.

Then came the draft night trade.

Orlando sent Oladipo, Ersan Ilyasova (acquired from Detroit in the Tobias Harris deal) and the 11th overall pick Domantas Sabonis to the Thunder for Serge Ibaka.

The Definitive 2017 Midseason NBA League Pass Rankings, Part II
Come for the hoops, stay for the hoops16winsaring.com

This was a clear win-now move by the Magic, turning two young assets (and Ilyasova) into an experienced vet that had his role reduced in Oklahoma City.

The deal would have made more sense had the Magic accompanied it with more complimentary signings in the offseason. Also, it would have helped to not trade for someone that plays the same position as their best young talent.

Signing a center in the offseason — Bismack Biyombo — was the big issue, as it flooded Orlando’s frontcourt once again. In today’s NBA, starting Ibaka at center with Gordon at power forward is an easy feat. It may not be what Ibaka is used to, but he’s a good rim protector and his shooting ability helps space out an offense that does not have many other starter-worthy shooting options.

But, Biyombo was signed, and Nikola Vucevic is still on board. There was no other option but starting Ibaka at the four. And since Gordon is — once again — the team’s best young talent, head coach Frank Vogel was forced to start him at small forward.

Becoming a starter alone, however, has still made this Gordon’s most productive season yet. He has career-highs in points, assists and three-point percentage.

The issue with Orlando being in win-now mode, however, is that Gordon’s usage percentage is below the likes of Nikola Vucevic, Evan Fournier, Serge Ibaka, Elfrid Payton and is tied with D.J. Augustin. Vucevic, Fournier, Ibaka and Payton are all relatively close, being separated by 2.9 percent or less. Gordon is a couple points below, and Orlando needs to move him up the ladder.

In the 10 games they’ve played in January, Gordon’s usage is even down a little bit from his season total, dipping from 19.8 to 19. Orlando is 2–8 in that time.

There is no telling whether featuring Gordon more would translate to wins, as he is still growing as a player. But using other players more isn’t working, so why not put the best young player behind the wheel and see how good of a driver he is?

A player Gordon may have a similar ceiling as is the one drafted two spots ahead of him in the 2014 draft: Jabari Parker.

Gordon would love to be in Parker’s situation right now. Not only does he play within a stable organization with a transcendent superstar on the rise, he is playing at the right position! And whenever Gordon is back at power forward full-time, he could end up being just as effective as Parker — who has burst onto the scene this season.

Aside from vertical leap and defensive upside, Gordon has nothing on Parker right now. Parker is living up to his potential after just a small improvement from his rookie to sophomore season, coming off the knee injury. Parker is just six months older than Gordon and has played the same amount of seasons, and yet, the 2014 No. 2 pick looks years older than the No. 4 pick.

To be fair, Gordon was much more of a project coming out of college than Parker. He was a raw, athletic forward with potential, while Parker was looked at as the most NBA-ready of the top prospects.

Despite some very good games this season, Gordon is still very raw. But, once he is fully developed, he could be in the same class as Parker.

Where Parker is especially further along than Gordon is confidence in his offensive game, which he seemingly struggled with in his first couple of seasons.

Parker can do enough on offense where defenses can no longer play off of him. Before this season, Parker’s main source of scoring was using his bag of tricks to get to the rim. His jab steps and quick first step allowed him to get around perimeter defenders, and his spin moves and strong body allowed him to finish at the rim over big men defending the paint.

That’s an area Gordon really needs to improve. Some of that is natural ability in Parker, but Gordon could certainly improve his craftiness in getting to the rim.

Parker will likely always have an edge in getting to the rim due to his combination of strength and quickness, but Gordon could certainly add more than the simplicity of overpowering his defender with an occasional spin move.

Because of Parker’s proven ability of getting to the rim, defenders would sag off of him as much as possible to do their best at shutting off his path to the rim. He could hit a jumpshot, but the three-point stroke wasn’t quite there yet.

Now, when defenders play off Parker, he pulls up with confidence and makes them regret it.

That three-point shot has arguably been Parker’s biggest improvement from last season to now. Last season, he shot 25.7 percent on just 0.5 attempts per game. Through 41 games this year, he is shooting 40.8 percent on 3.5 attempts.

Gordon has grown in that area, too, but he is not on Parker’s level yet. He jumped from 29.6 percent on 1.8 attempts last season to 32.5 percent on 3.5 attempts this season. Gordon is shooting about 37 percent on catch-and-shoot threes, which are the threes Gordon is taking the majority of the time. He has shot poorly on the few pull-up attempts he’s taken, but has shown some ability there. Below, Gordon comes off a screen and pulls up in rhythm, which looks pretty smooth.

Parker and Gordon are shooting the same amount of threes per game, but considering Gordon plays seven minutes less on average, he is shooting them a bit more frequently. If Gordon can creep closer to 40 percent from behind the arc, and his attempts go up with more minutes in the future, adding Parker’s driving tactics to his arsenal isn’t as important.

However, it would help if Gordon could improve that pull-up game; he’s shooting just 29 percent overall on pull-ups this season. Once his three-point shot is respected, his athleticism would allow him to easily scoot around defenders that are closing out. If there are no open lanes to the rim, a pull-up jumper could be an easy way for Gordon to score points.

Ultimately, it’s hard to compare Parker and Gordon as they are both different players right now and could end up being different players by their prime. That’s not necessarily the point, though. They could end up being similar players, or things could go another way. It depends on the type of player Gordon decides to become. They could both be similarly effective, just in different ways. Especially considering Gordon’s potential to eventually become a very good defender. He hasn’t done much on that end up to this point, but expecting a player on a rookie contract to be a plus-defender usually just leads to disappointment.

No one is expecting Gordon to be as good as Parker, but he has the tools on both ends of the floor to be a very good player someday. His improvement up to this point seems to show he is motivated to grow into that very good player, but the current state of the Magic is what’s holding back his development.

If the Magic decide to refocus their attention to developing their young core and ditch the win-now mentality, Aaron Gordon would have the opportunity to blossom into the franchise cornerstone Orlando has been long searching for.
